column4: if i do update-manager -d and upgrade everything, is upgrade going to be the lastest ubuntu? im asking this since i dont want to loose all configurations and software installed and start all over again... is it possible? is it ok to do this?
-d means it takes you to the deveopment version
but when final release is out, if i do that that will take me to lastest ubutnu, am i right?
no it ALWAYS means development version if you use -d
if you just want a stable release, thatll show in the top part of update-manager normally
if youre on a LTS release itll only show the next LTS by default. you change that in system -> administration -> software sources
so if i set it to normal releases and wait until 10.10 is out, i can upgrade to that version with synaptic?
so its "kinda" rolling release... i mean... i can have lastest version anyways and not loose all what ive done...
it's not rolling, no. the closest you get to rolling is constantly running the devel version
its just that it allows upgrade-over-the-internet
the release names in /etc/apt/sources.list will still be updated for example
great... thanks, i was thinking on moving to rolling release distro, but i see now how it works...
